title: Apple Seeks Delay on Court Ruling Barring App Payment Commissions
summary: Apple is trying to delay a court ruling that forces the company to let iOS app developers accept payments via non-Apple systems and avoid paying a cut.
full_text_content:
In an attempt to protect a valuable revenue stream, Apple is trying to delay a court ruling that forces the company to let iOS app developers in the U.S. redirect users to external payment systems and avoid paying a commission to the iPhone maker.
The company filed an emergency motion late on Wednesday, asking an appeals court to grant a partial stay on a previous ruling.
A U.S. court last week ruled in favor of Epic Games in a long-running case against Apple, after Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers found that Apple did not comply with an order that was handed down in 2021.
The new ruling forces Apple to let apps on its U.S. App Store include features that could redirect users to external systems for making purchases, stop collecting commissions on those payments, and stop showing “scare screens” — pop-up messages warning users of the dangers of making in-app purchases from non-Apple systems.
Apple is now asking for a stay on the prohibitions on “charging a cut of transactions that users make via external purchase links, and setting any conditions on the language or placement of links or other references to external purchase options.”
Apple argues that the new ruling is unwarranted, saying it “dramatically” increases the scope of the earlier injunction, as the court did not originally bar the company from charging commissions on non-Apple payment systems — Apple had not started doing that at the time.
Apple says it complied with the court’s 2021 injunction by letting developers link out to non-Apple payment systems. We must note that it charged app developers a 27% cut on those transactions anyway, in addition to showing the “scare screens” described above.

The new order would result in significant losses, the company said. “These restrictions, which will cost Apple substantial sums annually, are based on conduct that has never been adjudicated to be (and is not) unlawful; rather, they were imposed to punish Apple for purported non-compliance with an earlier state-law Injunction that is itself invalid,” it said in the filing.
“Without a stay, these extraordinary intrusions into Apple’s business will cause grave irreparable harm,” the company said.
The iPhone maker filed an appeal against the court decision earlier this week. The company has already complied with the order and is allowing developers to link users out to complete purchases outside the App Store ecosystem. Companies like Spotify and Amazon have already updated their apps to redirect users to their own websites for payments.

## Apple Seeks Delay on Court Ruling Barring App Payment Commissions Apple has filed an emergency motion to delay a court ruling that would prevent the company from collecting commissions on payments made outside its App Store ecosystem. The ruling, issued last week in favor of Epic Games, requires Apple to allow U.S. developers to redirect users to external payment systems without charging fees or displaying warnings. The iPhone maker argues that the decision expands the scope of a 2021 injunction and could cause "grave irreparable harm" to its business. Apple has already complied with part of the order by permitting external payment links but continues to impose a 27% fee on such transactions. ### Legal Battle and Financial Stakes The latest ruling stems from a long-running antitrust case brought by Epic Games, which challenged Apple's control over in-app payments. Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers found that Apple failed to fully comply with the 2021 injunction, leading to stricter enforcement. The new order prohibits Apple from collecting commissions on external transactions and restricts its ability to influence how developers present alternative payment options. Apple contends that the court overstepped by penalizing the company for conduct not previously deemed unlawful. In its filing, Apple warned of "substantial sums annually" in lost revenue if the ruling takes effect. The company has already appealed the decision, signaling a prolonged legal battle ahead. #### Developer Reactions and Market Impact Major app developers like Spotify and Amazon have already updated their apps to bypass Apple's payment system, taking advantage of the 2021 injunction. The new ruling could accelerate this trend, further eroding Apple's lucrative App Store fees, which contribute significantly to its services revenue. However, smaller developers may hesitate to adopt external payment systems due to Apple's continued enforcement of its 27% commission. The court's decision to block "scare screens" could level the playing field, but Apple's latest legal maneuver suggests the fight is far from over. #### Frequently Asked Questions
What does the court ruling require Apple to do?

The ruling bars Apple from charging commissions on payments made via external links and restricts the company from displaying warnings about non-Apple payment systems.

Why is Apple seeking a delay?

Apple claims the ruling expands the original injunction unfairly and could cause significant financial harm. The company argues it has already complied with the 2021 order by allowing external payment links.

How have developers responded?

Companies like Spotify and Amazon have already integrated external payment options, while smaller developers may still face challenges due to Apple's 27% fee on out-of-store transactions.
